sentences.sentence: With respect to your other more serious accusation( 责备 ) regarding Mr. Wickham, I have no choice but to explain the entire story of his connection with my family.
Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who had worked for my father for many years managing my family’s finances( 财产 ).
My father, therefore, chose to support the younger Mr. Wickham at school, and then at Cambridge.
My father was not only fond of this young man’s company, but also had a very high opinion of him.
He hoped the church would be his profession, and intended( 打算 ) to help establish( 安排 ) him in it.
As for myself, it has been many, many years since I first began to think of Mr. Wickham in a very different way.
He was always careful to never reveal( 暴露 ) himself to my father, but since I was a young man of nearly the same age as him I could not help but see who he truly was.
I had the opportunity to see him in his unguarded moments, which my father could not have.
My excellent father died about five years ago, and he remained very fond of Mr. Wickham right until the very end.
In his will he specifically( 特别地 ) wrote that I should do all that I could to help Mr. Wickham advance as far as possible in his career( 职业 ),
and that if he joined the Church, I should provide him with a valuable position at one of the churches controlled by our family as soon as one became available.
Mr. Wickham also received an inheritance( 遗产 ) of one thousand pounds.
Within half a year from these events, Mr. Wickham wrote to inform me that he had finally decided against joining the Church.
He hoped I would not find it unreasonable that he now expected to receive some financial( 经济上的 ) assistance( 帮助 ), since he could no longer rely( 依靠 ) on an income from that profession.
He also added that he was now planning to study law, and one thousand pounds would not be enough to support him in that profession.
I hoped that he was sincere( 真诚的 ), in wanting to study law, even though I already suspected( 怀疑 ) that he was not.
In any case, I knew by this time that Mr. Wickham was certainly not suited to the Church.
The business was therefore soon settled—he would give up all claim to assistance( 帮助 ) in the church, and in return would accept three thousand pounds.
This seemed to be put an end to any remaining connection, and for about three years I heard very little of him.
I heard that he was living in London, but that his studying of law was only a pretense( 借口 ) and that he was leading a life of idleness( 闲散 ) and dissipation( 浪费 ).
Then I received another letter from him.
In this letter, he explained that his circumstances( 境遇 ) were now exceedingly( 极其地 ) bad.
He had not been successful at all in the law, and had now absolutely( 绝对地 ) decided to join the church again.
All I needed to do was to give him the assistance( 帮助 ) which he had been promised.
He said he was certain that I would not object to this, since I could not have forgotten my beloved( 挚爱的 ) father’s intentions.
I am sure you will not blame me for refusing to agree, even when he repeated the request on many occasions.
He was as angry as he was desperate( 绝望的 )—and I am sure he abused( 辱骂 ) me as badly to others as he did to my face.
I do not know how he lived during this period, but soon he again came to my notice in the most painful way.
I must now mention a circumstance( 境遇 ) which I would honestly prefer to forget, and which nothing other than the present circumstances( 境遇 ) could force me to tell to any human being.
Having said this, I have no doubts about your secrecy.
My sister, who is ten years younger than I am, was placed in the care of myself and my cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam, after my father’s death.
About a year ago, she was taken from school, and moved to London.

Mrs. Younge, the housekeeper( 管家 ), took her to Ramsgate, and Mr. Wickham also went there as part of a plot with Mrs. Younge, a woman whom we trusted and who betrayed( 背叛 ) us in the worst possibly manner.

There, with Mrs. Younge’s help, he made himself so attractive to Georgiana, who still remembered him from Pemberley, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love, and agreed to a secret marriage to him.
She was then only fifteen, which must be her excuse, and I am happy to add that I discovered this information from Georgiana herself.
I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before their planned escape together.
It was then that Georgiana, unable to cause pain to the brother whom she looked up to( 尊敬 ) almost as a father, told me everything.
You may imagine what I felt and how I acted.
Mr. Wickham’s main goal was undoubtedly my sister’s wealth, for she will have thirty thousand pounds once she marries or turns twenty-one.
But I also cannot help but think that he meant to seek revenge( 报复 ) against me.
If he had succeeded in taking my sister from me in such a way, his revenge( 报复 ) would have been complete indeed.
This, madam( 女士 ), is a truthful telling of every event in which Wickham and I have been concerned together.
If you wish to, you may confirm( 核实 ) these details( 细节 ) with Colonel Fitzwilliam, who has been involved in many of these events and was the executor( 执行人 ) of my father’s will.
I will only add: God bless you.
FITZWILLIAM DARCY.
